Subgroup

Let $G$ be a monoid. A subset $H \subset G$ is called a submonoid if $H$ satisfies the following conditions: (i) $e \in H$, (ii) $a, b \in H \Longrightarrow a b \in H$. If $G$ is a group, $H$ is called a subgroup of $G$ if in addition, (iii) $a \in H \Longrightarrow a^{-1} \in H$. In particular, a subgroup of a group $G$ is a submonoid that is closed under the process of taking inverses. In defining a subgroup $H \subset G$, condition (i) can be weakened by simply requiring $H \neq \emptyset$, since this implies $e \in H$ using (ii) and (iii). Of course, similar reasoning is not possible for monoids. Every group $G$ admits $\{e\}$ and $G$ as trivial subgroups. Given $m \in \mathbb{Z}$, the set $m \mathbb{Z}$ consisting of all integral multiples of $m$ is a subgroup of the additive group $\mathbb{Z}$. We will see in 1.3/4 that all subgroups of $\mathbb{Z}$ are of this type. More generally, every element $a$ of a group $G$ gives rise to a so-called cyclic subgroup of $G$. It consists of all powers $a^{n}, n \in \mathbb{Z}$, where we put $a^{n}=\left(a^{-1}\right)^{-n}$ for $n<0; see also Section 1.3.
Dedekind Domain

A Dedekind domain is an integral domain in which the theorem on unique prime factorization holds for ideals. It is a nonzero ring without nontrivial zero divisors, and Dedekind's theorem on unique prime factorization for ideals is applicable.
Units of a Ring
For a ring R, the set of multiplicatively invertible elements is denoted by R*. These elements are called the units of R.
System of Generators of an Ideal

Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an ideal of a ring $R$. A family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of elements in $\mathfrak{a}$ is called a system of generators of $\mathfrak{a}$ if $\mathfrak{a}=\sum_{i \in I} R a_{i}$, i.e., if $\mathfrak{a}$ coincides with the ideal generated by the family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$.
Euclidean domain

An integral domain $R$ is called a Euclidean domain if it admits a map $\delta: R-\{0\} \longrightarrow \mathbb{N}$ making possible Euclidean division in $R$ in the following sense: Given elements $f, g \in R, g \neq 0$, there are elements $q, r \in R$ such that $f=q g+r$, where $\delta(r)<\delta(g)$ or $r=0$.
Canonical Homomorphism
The canonical homomorphism $\\[Phi: R[X] \\longrightarrow R /(p)[X]\\]$ is a ring homomorphism that reduces the coefficients of a polynomial modulo a prime element $p$ in $R$.
Separable Polynomial
A separable polynomial is a polynomial that has distinct roots in its splitting field, i.e., all roots are simple.
Algebraically closed field

A field $K$ is called algebraically closed if every nonconstant polynomial $f$ of $K[X]$ admits a zero in $K$, or in other words, if $f$ decomposes in $K[X]$ into a product of linear factors. This means that $f$ admits a product decomposition $f=c \prod_{i}\left(X-\alpha_{i}\right)$ with a constant $c \in K^{*}$ as well as zeros $\alpha_{i} \in K$.
K-homomorphism
A field homomorphism \\(\sigma: L \longrightarrow L'\\) between two field extensions \\(L / K\\) and \\(L' / K\\) is called a \\(K\\)-homomorphism if it restricts to the identity map on \\(K\\).
Ideal corresponding to a subset
Given a subset \(U \subset \bar{K}^{n}\), the corresponding ideal \(I(U)\) in the polynomial ring \(K[X]\) consists of all polynomials that vanish on \(U\).
p-group
A finite group G is called a p-group if the order of G is a power of p, where p is a prime number.
Domain
The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values for which the function is defined. Every input value in the domain has a corresponding output in the codomain via the function.
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A subgroup is defined as a subset of a group that satisfies certain conditions. Therefore, the concept of a group must be defined to understand what a subgroup is.
A Dedekind domain is defined as an integral domain with specific properties. Therefore, the concept of an integral domain must be defined to understand what a Dedekind domain is.
The units of a ring are defined as the set of multiplicatively invertible elements in a ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what the units of a ring are.
A system of generators of an ideal is defined in terms of an ideal of a ring. Therefore, the concept of an ideal must be defined to understand what a system of generators of an ideal is.

A Euclidean domain is defined as an integral domain with a specific property related to Euclidean division. Therefore, the concept of an integral domain must be defined to understand what a Euclidean domain is.
The canonical homomorphism is defined as a ring homomorphism. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a canonical homomorphism is.

An algebraically closed field is defined as a field where every nonconstant polynomial has a zero in the field. Therefore, the concept of a field must be defined to understand what an algebraically closed field is.
A K-homomorphism is defined as a field homomorphism between two field extensions. Therefore, the concept of a field must be defined to understand what a K-homomorphism is.
An ideal corresponding to a subset is defined in terms of a polynomial ring. Therefore, the concept of a polynomial ring must be defined to understand what an ideal corresponding to a subset is.
